title: theresa may brexit postpone eu leaders
story: The Prime Minister defied her critics this morning to insist she has no plans to put off the crucial Commons showdown.She told the BBC today: We’re in the middle of  days of debate which will lead to a vote on this issue... they are voting on the deal.And she refused several times to be drawn on whether she could cancel it altogether.At least three Cabinet ministers are believed to be trying to persuade the PM to put the December  vote off. And Labour plans to issue a vote of no confidenceMay loses.According to the Daily Mail, one said: We need to be creative and we need to get the DUP back on board. It can be done, but it cant be done before next Tuesday.Another said: Marching people into the valley of death next Tuesday is a mistake.With the clock ticking, and unrest across Parliament, some senior Tories have suggested she delay the vote.According to the , EU leaders would offer her a chance to extend the Article  deadlineshe is voted down in the Commons next Tuesday.It could give Britain more time to negotiate a deal before the March  axe falls.But Downing Street has always ruled out a date change.Senior Tories on both sides of the Brexit ide predicted Britains EU departure date of March  will now be delayed as ministers will be forced to put together a new softer option to please Parliament.The news comes as:May is trying to salvage her deal and win over Conservative dissenters by giving a MPs a vote on the Northern Irish backstop, she confirmed this morning.The PM revealed her last-ditch plans today to try and win around Tory rebels into supporting her deal next week, as she faces almost certain defeat.Damning legal advice yesterday revealed the backstop plan for Northern Ireland would tie us down to the EU forever - which is one of the main reasons MPs hate her deal so much.Mrs May acknowledged today that people have a concern of the backstop, that we could be in it definitely but argued that the other option of staying in a transition would mean paying more money to the EU and accepting unlimited EU immigration for longer too.She said that killing off her proposals could end up in the UK leaving the bloc with No Deal - or would risk no Brexit.Earlier this week there was fury as Tory rebels backed Labour in a coup to inflict a landmark defeat on the Government.Ministers were voted to be in contempt of Parliament for the first time ever - and were forced to release a stream of legal documents which proved her deal risks splitting Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK “indefinitely”.And a separate vote proposed by rebel Tory Dominic Grieve gave MPs the power for what happens in the event that Parliament rejects her deal next week.But International Trade Secretary Liam Fox blasted it as a plot to “steal Brexit from the British people”.The DUP, which props up her administration, warned they wont carry on backing the partyshe ploughs on with the plans.

title: theresa may brexit deal vote
story: The PM revealed her last-ditch plans today to try and win around Tory rebels into supporting her deal next week, as she faces almost certain defeat.She told Radio  that MPs would have a decision by the end of  over whether they wanted to avoid the hated Northern Ireland backstop.Mrs May said that would be a choice between going into the backstop and extending the transition period.She said she was talking to people about the role of Parliament in deciding what happens next - and there would be pros and cons of both sides of that.The backstop is not automatic, she stressed.Damning legal advice yesterday revealed the backstop plan for Northern Ireland would tie us down to the EU forever - which is one of the main reasons MPs hate her deal so much.Mrs May acknowledged today that people have a concern of the backstop, that we could be in it definitely but argued that the other option of staying in a transition would mean paying more money to the EU and accepting unlimited EU immigration for longer too.She said that killing off her proposals could end up in the UK leaving the bloc with No Deal - or would risk no Brexit.The PM also confirmed that she IS still planning on pushing ahead with a crunch vote on Tuesday, even though shes likely to be crushed by her own MPs.Last night it was revealed that Cabinet ministers have been begging her to scrap the vote altogether.But she told the BBC: We are in the middle of five days of debate in Parliament which will lead up to a vote on this issue.But  per cent of them said the EU WONT offer Britain a better dealshe goes, and MPs must vote for the deal on the table.Almost half of them said it was too late to stop Brexit, but a third said it wasnt.But ideally, the public would want MPs to vote against Mrs Mays deal - by  per cent to  per cent.The poll puts some pressure on MPs to back Mrs Mays deal, suggesting they think its the only realistic option.The news comes as:Mrs May also said this morning that any agreement must include the backstop in some way.She said: There is no deal without a backstop.Earlier this week there was fury as Tory rebels backed Labour in a coup to inflict a landmark defeat on the Government.Ministers were voted to be in contempt of Parliament for the first time ever - and were forced to release a stream of legal documents which proved her deal risks splitting Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK “indefinitely”.And a separate vote proposed by rebel Tory Dominic Grieve gave MPs the power for what happens in the event that Parliament rejects her deal next week.The DUP - Mrs Mays Northern Irish allies - have warned they wont carry on backing the Governmentshe wins the vote.

title: hooray uk parliament doing job
story: NewsopinionHooray! The UK Parliament is doing its job properly for the first time in almost a decadeThis is how democracy is supposed to work, peopleShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen politicians are unsure, they ask the people to decide. When the people cant, they tell politicians to figure it out. The courts pick their way through the detail trying to be fair to all sides, and only the journalists try to explain why its complicated. So it is with capital punishment, terrorism, drone strikes, tax reforms, benefit cuts and everything  in le. Most of us expect complexity, relying on others to help us find a balance that doesnt kill us. We vote for representatives, then ask them to rely on their judgement to decide everything until we demand they rely on ours. But with Brexit the whole things gone cockeyed. We voted for those who suggested our relationship with the EU was simple. Parliament voted enthusiastically for a simple referendum. The people gave a simple answer, the government issued a simple letter. The courts were the first ones to decide it was complicated and journalists have spent the past two years failing to explain much at all. Its hardly surprising were now in a world where simple people still demand a simple Brexit and that politicians rely on the people to figure it out for them. A ComRes poll shows that people oppose remaining in the EU, oppose leaving with Theresa Mays deal, oppose a second referendum and oppose leaving without a deal. Their big idea instead is to renegotiate, despite the fact weve done that for two years and all the clowns achieved was a joke buttonhole that squirts water at the EU infor poundbillion. Politicians are now so confused about whos supposed to be doing what that the Disgraced Dr Liam Fox says theres a real danger that MPs may attempt to stealBrexit from the British people, and Michael Gove said that not delivering a simple thing that isnt possible because its more complicated than that would be a fatal blow to faith in democracy. Andrea Leadsom smilingly added that Parliamentarians who want to be in government in the future will live to regret the decision they took last night, as though she were a Mafia consigliere threatening painful retribution against those who disrespected the Prime Minister. Lets just stop there. Lets go back a bit, and explain. In  there was a massive, global, banking crash. Had it been ignored by politicians everyone would be living out of dustbins by now. All right, Richard Branson would be in Necker and Alan Sugar on his yacht, but it would be dustbins for them too.   Politicians worldwide did their jobs and figured out a solution. Two years later there was a general election and the people couldnt pick a team, so politicians had to form their own. Bizarrely, the party that came second wasnt part of it. The not-quite winners teamed up with the actual-losers and took power with barely a flicker of democratic concern.In the years that followed they housed immigrants in areas that rarely voted for their parties. Despite the fact such people produced more tax than they spent, they cut services in those places more than in friendlier ones. The aim, and result, was that Labour-voting areas became more xenophobic and more likely to turn Tory on immigration issues. They declared the previous administration profligate, then accumulated so many debts theyve started selling them off. They promised a northern powerhouse, while investing poundbn in the south and cutting investment by poundbn in the north.Thats not normal behaviour for politicians of any stripe, as theyre usually fully aware they can be sacked at short notice. But THIS lot established fixed, five-year contracts, which meant democracy was limited.When we were finally allowed a vote, the people picked the team which had been doing all the above but pretending that it wasnt. That team then opted to protect itself - not the country - by offering a referendum on leaving the EU which it thought no-one would want to do. But the people, now thoroughly confused by lies, theft, quantitative easing, Question Time, austerity, bananas and everything  hurled at them for years, picked the easy road - the f*** it road. The team captains ran away, the pound noseed, and those left on the field started barking the chaos was all Project Fear and could be completely ignored.   A new team captain activated Article  and told Parliament it had no say. The courts intervened to say Parliament was sovereign. Newspapers said judges were the enemy. Parliament was cowed into backing Article , even though it was vague and fully-revokable.The government then spent two years not negotiating a deal that isnt actually a deal, before telling the people and Parliament its the only option when it isnt. Few people notice that were preparing to leave the EU with , more people in poverty than we had  years ago, or have asked whether Brexit is in their interests.When the four estates of a democratic nation are in such turmoil and acting in direct opposition to their normal roles, there is nothing to do but hold on and hope for the best. And now, the ship of state is righting itself. Journalists are explaining complexities and detail. Judges are regarded as refuge. And Parliament has, finally, begun holding government to account.   For the first time in history, those ruling the country have been proven to be in contempt of our democratic processes. For the first time since the Brexit vote, the government has been forced to bow to the will of those figuring things out on behalf of the people. And for the first time in  years the Mother of Parliaments is acting like a grown-up - something that happens when loyal MPs rebel for a principle, when politicians seek to listen to one anothers arguments, when the people take an interest in what is being decided on their behalf. Nothing is perfect. We live in a world where racists claim the same freedom of expression as journalists, and believe that makes it all right to hurl homophobic slurs at a columnist while chasing him down the street, to threaten Jewish MPs online, to cause BBC reporters to need bodyguards. In the past decade, the confusion in our system has been fed by fake news, populism and idiots. The reason that these things - more properly called propaganda, fascism and the unelectable - do not dominate our world is because the system self-corrects. Each part pushes and pulls against the others, and the result is stable, slow, progress.  That is what happened in Parliament yesterday. Its what, hopefully, will continue this week while they vote on Brexit. Remember ityou are asked to vote again. Remember it when a journalist tries to explain, when judges rule, when MPs rebel and amend and argue. Elsewhere, with Parliaments that do not scrutinise the government, dictators hold power. Where journalists cannot explain, the people are kept in ignorance. And where those things are actively attacked, the world grows dark -  journalists were murdered this year while  languish in jail, most of them for crimes against the state. While Putin and Bin Salman high-five after the dismemberment of a journalist, remember that reporters are the first bit of democracy that dies. In their wake come the opponents, the judges, and then the people. However confusing and chaotic your democracy is, hold on to it. Be glad you have an MP, especiallythey dont always do as theyre told. Seek out a journalist whos explained well and say thank you, because the occasional pat is the only encouragement they need to keep headbutting walls. Note what happens when people dont vote, and make sure you do. Above all, be glad you have an opportunity to argue about your nations direction, and that youre not the only one steering the ship.

title: pm offers veto irish backstop
story: NewsPM May offers veto on Irish backstop in plea for Brexit support in crunch voteTheresa May was in private talks this week to win over sceptics before the end of her five day countdown to Brexit voteShareCommentsByPippa Crerar:,  DEC NewsPrime Minister Theresa May has five days to convince Brexit sceptics to back her plan "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May was desperately trying to win over Tory rebels to night by offering them a veto on the Irish backstop. With just five days to go until the crunch vote on her Brexit deal, the Prime Minister held private talks with sceptical Brexiteers to try and avert a crushing defeat. It came as the Government was forced to publish legal advice it tried to keep confidential, which confirmed the UK would be unable to quit the backstop without the EU’s permission. The backstop keeps Northern Ireland in a customs union to avoid a hard border on the -mile frontier with EU member Ireland. The Democratic Unionist Party, which props up Mrs May’s fragile government, launched a furious attack on the “devastating” advice. Nigel Dodds, the Northern Irish party’s shyWestminster leader, said: “The union of the United Kingdom is non-negotiable”. Read the full Brexit legal advice document   In a sign of how poor relations are between the two parties, the DUP suggested their  MPs would be willing to back Mrs May in a no-confidence vote onlyMPs first voted down her Brexit deal. Yet Downing Street claimed the Tory-DUP deal was still in place and that Northern Ireland would get the full poundbillion they had been promised. And whips are still concerned her premiership could come crashing downTory Brexiteer MPs support Labour in a confidence vote. Mrs May wants to broker a compromise plan to get rebellious MPs to back her which could include giving them a parliamentary “lock” on the backstop. It would mean the Government’s insurance policy to avoid a hard border with Irelanda trade deal is not struck would only come into forceMPs approved it. A No source said: “She understands people still have concerns and will be talking to colleagues.” Chief whip Julian Smith was despatched to a meeting of the hardline ERG group of Brexiteers to try to win them over. But with more than  Conservatives now stating that they are going to oppose the Government, the scale of the challenge looked insurmountable. MPs dismissed her “lock” proposals as a fig leaf. Former Brexit minister Steve Baker said: “It’s a silly idea few will fall for”. Brussels appeared to be preparing for Mrs May’s deal being voted down by putting Article , which triggered Brexit, on the agenda of next week’s EU summit.   It raised speculation that leaders might delay the UK’s departure date to July, in order to give Mrs May more time. The six-page legal advice by Attorney General Geoffrey Cox QC said the UK could become mired for years in negotiations with Brussels with no power to leave. The EU could apply to an shyarbitration  for Northern Ireland to remain in the EU customs area after Great Britain left, Mr Cox advised. Despite assurances the backstop,used, would be temporary, the situation would “endure indefinitely” until a trade agreement was reached. Mr Cox admitted it “does not provide for a mechanism that is likely to enable the UK lawfully to exit the UK-wide customs union without a subsequent agreement”. He warned the risk was “a political decision for the Government”. Mrs May insisted both she and Mr Cox had openly said the backstop was shyindefinite without a final trade deal. Mr Dodds said his party’s opposition to the deal had been vindicated.   “The legal advice just published proves Northern Ireland would be in full shyEuropean Union Customs Union while Great Britain is not,” he said. “This backstop is totally unacceptable to unionists and it must be defeated and arrangements renegotiated that uphold the commitments which the Prime Minister and her Government made.” Blasting the attempt to keep the advice secret, Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said: “All that this advice reveals is the central weaknesses in the Government’s deal. It is unthinkable it tried to keep this information from Parliament and the public before next week’s vote.” Meanwhile, Labour MPs were surprised that Jeremy Corbyn opted not to attack Mrs May on Brexit at Prime Minister’s Questions following one of the most turbulent days of her premiership. And Unite General Secretary Len McCluskey, one of the Labour leader’s closest allies, dealt a blow to second referendum campaigners by suggesting voters would see it as a betrayal.The UK faces a new year recession as Brexit fears crush business and consumer confidence, economists predict. Chris Williamson, of IHS Markit, said: “The possibility of no deal has caused companies and customers to cancel spending.”

title: theresa loses brexit vote what
story: NewsIf Theresa May loses the Brexit vote this is what could happen nextThe Prime Minister appears doomed to certain defeat, unable to cobble together the numbers to force her blueprint through the CommonsShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politicsBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  DEC NewsTheresa May faces the fight of her political le "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf  MPs back Theresa May’s Brexit deal she will emerge victorious on Tuesday. The Tories have  MPs, plus she has a confidence and supply deal with Northern Ireland’s Democratic Unionist Party, so all will be well for the Prime Minister, yes  Emphatically, no. In fact, she appears doomed to certain defeat, unable to cobble together the numbers to force her blueprint through the Commons. Thanks to Mrs May needlessly squandering David Cameron’s hard-won,fragile, majority at last year’s snap general election - the one she never needed to call - she has to rely on the DUP to win parliamentary votes. But despite the poundbillion bung she conjured up for the Ulster hardliners, the DUP will not support the pact because elements of the deal would make Northern Ireland dferent from the rest of the UK. That strips away the PM’s stitched-together majority in a trice. In her own party, insiders believe up to nine Tory Remainers could vote against the deal, piling further pressure on the premier.   And then there is the European Research Group, a seemingly innocent name for the Conservatives’ hardline Brexiteers. Scores of its members are set to revolt unless Mrs May conjures a compromise. Sources estimate up to  Tory MPs could vote against the deal. While some Labour MPs may rebel against Jeremy Corbyn and offer their support, it is highly unlikely to be anywhere near enough to save the PM’s pact. What happened in the Commons yesterday  Theresa May lost three crucial votes. MPs backed a Labour amendment which held the Government in contempt for refusing to publish its full legal advice on the Brexit plan. The advice will now be released, and could confirm the worst fears of the Brexiteers – making even more of them likely to vote down the deal. Then MPs backed an amendment by Tory MP Dominic Grieve which would give MPs a say on what happensTheresa May’s Brexit deal is voted down. This means they could block a no-deal Brexit, send the Prime Minister back to the negotiating table or even call for a second referendum. The PM is no longer in control of Parliament or the Brexit process.   Can Brexit be halted  Remainers have seized on the provisional findings of the The European Court of Justice’s advocate general, who said the UK can decide on its own to cancel its withdrawal from the EU. It is not a binding judgment but suggests the ECJ will come to the same conclusion in its official ruling. This would allow us to revoke Article , the two-year mechanism Mrs May triggered which started the countdown to our departure on March , . What happens next  The key moment is on Tuesday when MPs vote on Mrs May’s Brexit plan. Unless she persuades Tory rebels to change their mind she is heading for almost certain defeat. More than  Conservative MPs, the DUP, the vast majority of Labour MPs,  Lib Dems and the SNP have all said they will vote down the proposal. But some Brexiteers may take fright at Mr Grieve’s amendment, fearing it could scupper Brexit. What does the Prime Minister doshe loses  We are in uncharted territory. The law says Mrs May has toto Parliament within  days with an updated response. Much will depend on the scale of defeat. If it is close she could try to wring further concessions from Brussels. If she is heavily defeated she will be under intense pressure to resign.   Where does that leave Brexit  Nobody knows. MPs could send the PM back to Brussels but that would need the EU to agree to extend Article . Or Mrs May could call a snap election. This is a high-risk move for the Tories as it could land Jeremy Corbyn in No . MPs could also decide only a second referendum can break the deadlock. The default is that we crash out without a deal. But most MPs will do everything they can to prevent what they see as an economic calamity.

title: couple living tent after being
story: NewsEvicted couple living in a tent are crowdfunding for a home for ChristmasRachel Melbourne and her partner Lee Grantham from Hull say they are living a "nightmare" and "would not put our worst enemies in this situation"ShareCommentsByAlex Grove:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe couple wake up in their tent every morning freezing "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA homeless couple who have been living in a tent for six months are desperately trying to raise cash to find a home in time for Christmas. Rachel Melbourne, , and her partner Lee Grantham, , have been forced to sleep rough after being evicted from their house in Hull. The pair claim they were stripped of their belongings and left with just the clothes on their backs after ing to the house in June to find it boarded up with their two dogs still inside. With nowhere to turn they have been camping out in a tent in a friend’s back garden, reports Hull Live.   Miss Melbourne said: “It’s unbearable and it’s got to the point now where we have nowhere to turn and nothing to lose. No one seems to be interested in wanting to help us. “It’s freezing and we wake up every morning with ice all over the tent.We’ve been getting really poorly and really chesty because of the damp – especially Lee who is awake all night coughing. “We can’t go to the toilet, we can’t get a bath or a shower and we’ve only got the clothes we were left with.We’ve got two airbeds which keep deflating and a quilt but we still wake up with wet inside the tent.” The couple had lived in their home since January  and the day after their eviction, Miss Melbourne says her boyfriend was attacked outside the house in relation to the dispute.  On July , the pair suffered further heartbreak after being forced to put down their fox terrier Lucy with vets believing the animal could have suffered after being “struck in the stomach.” They have contacted Hull City Council and were placed on the housing list four months ago but they are still yet to find a home with Christmas just weeks away. Miss Melbourne’s stepson has had to stay with his grandmother while she lives in a tent and in a desperate bid to find a home in time for Christmas the couple have started a crowdfunding page to try and raise pound,. She is urging people to find it in their hearts to give them any spare change they have so they can escape the “nightmare” they are currently enduring. She said: “Words can’t explain how much it would mean to us to have a home. We need a base to get our lives back because we’ve lost everything and we are drained. “We have both thought ‘what is the point of being here ’ because no one seems to care. “If anyone has got a heart I would urge them to help because we would not put our worst enemies in this situation. To have everything you own taken away from you and not being able to do anything about it is terrible. “It has been a nightmare and I wouldn’t wish it on anyone.” You can donate to Miss Melbourne’s crowdfunding page by clicking here .

title: duchess cambridge grins bears royal
story: NewsDuchess of Cambridge grins and bears royal le despite rumours of Meghan rtKate was all smiles, along with husband William, as they delivered gts to troopsShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  DEC NewsThe Duchess of Cambridge, Queen of the Grins "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThere has been much speculation recently about supposed tensions with Meghan – but Kate’s broad grin today was a megawatt one. It’s been a similar story in a series of appearances by the Duchess of Cambridge in recent weeks. And she brought a smile to the faces of troops and their families as she and William played Santa yesterday. The couple delivered gts to troops at RAF Akrotiri, home of the Cyprus Operations Support Unit, from loved ones back home who they met at a party at Kensington Palace the day before. Squadron Leader Sarah Waghorn, whose -year-old dad David had met the royals at their party, said: “They said their parcel service ‘really was the royal mail’.” Ex-helicopter pilot William praised the , sailors, soldiers, airmen and marines deployed over the festive period in  operations across  countries. He said: “From my time in unorm, Catherine and I both know a bit of what it feels like to balance your work commitments with your family le.  “You all put duty first. And so do your families. We know this isn’t easy.” Scott Stewart, , a communications specialist from RAF Spadeadam in Cumbria, who spoke to the couple, said: “Kate said how time [with children] means so much, especially in the early years so it’s great to have them recognise the sacrices we’re making.” The couple’s own kids George, five, Charlotte, three, and seven-month-old Louis stayed back home – but George took a keen interest in the visit. William told pilots in the sergeants’ mess: “I told him this morning we were going to see the pilots today, and he said, ‘If you see a shyhelicopter can you take a picture ’” William and Kate, both , later opened a recreation centre at the base. Spotting bright yellow sofas in the video room, William teased the troops: “Keep the pizza off the sofas!” Kate quipped to him: “You’re a nightmare with that!”  Kate has faced rumours of a rt with the Duchess of Sussex, fuelled by news that Meghan and Harry will no longer be moving next to William and Kate at Kensington Palace. It followed reports that Kate was left in tears at daughter Charlotte’s bridesmaid dress fitting for Meghan’s wedding to Harry in May. title: family told wait cold table
story: NewsFamily told to wait in cold for table at Burger King despite place being EMPTYChris Sharp, , from Merseyside claims that he and his family were told they could not come in as the fast food restaurant was too busy - despite there being no one insideShareCommentsByTom Houghton:,  DEC NewsChris Sharp has claimed that Burger King told his family to wait in the cold for table despite restaurant being empty "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStaff at a new Burger King apparently reduced children to tears after allegedly making them wait outside in the cold for a table - despite the restaurant appearing to be empty. Chris Sharp, , and his family were on a walk in New Brighton, Merseyside when they decided to visit the fast-food restaurant which recently opened. Looking to get shelter from the cold weather, and noticing several empty tables, they approached the eatery. However the father-of-five claims that staff told them it was too busy to come in and would not even let them wait in the doorway - despite the family seeing plenty of empty tables inside. Chris said: I was amazed, and askedthey were actually being serious. The kids just wanted a burger - they were freezing. I said cant we just wait in the door  All we were met with was a point blank no, and the door shut.  I couldnt believe the attitude - no explanation or anything. I think its ridiculous the way we were treated. A disgrace. Chris, who was with three of his young children and we Ashleigh at the time, said the family ended up going to Subway instead. Describing the situation, which is said to have happened on Sunday, he said: We went for a walk along New Brighton promenade because the weather was looking alright. We got to Fort Perch Rock and it started to get chilly.The kids were moaning that they were hungry so we decided to go to Burger King. But there were two people working there stood outside who told us you cant come in. They said the kitchen is busy so you have to wait outside for  to  minutes. Chris continued: I said whats the problem  Weve got an eight month old in the pram and a three-year-old I was carrying. By the time we have sat down and taken our coats off itd be about  minutes anyway, but they said no, youre not coming in. So we were left outside in the cold. Shocking.  We looked into the restaurant and there was no one at the till and only about eight or nine people sitting down eating. I was fuming to be honest. The kids were crying. Chris said it was doubly disappointing because there has been so much hype about the new restaurant opening recently. When askedthere was any chance he wouldto the store in future, he said: No chance. The way we were spoken to was disgusting. I couldnt believe it. It comes after the world-famous chain said it would open its new store with a brand new prime design, having received planning permission.  In November, it had advertisement consent approved by the council for its new signs - to bring the premises over to the Burger King brand. Approving the proposals, which were submitted in September, the council documents said: The proposed fascia signs are al and relate to the business premises, they do not have a detrimental impact on the character of the area, the building concerned and its neighbours and are therefore considered acceptable. Burger King was contacted for comment about the incident.

title: revolutionary dna test birth help
story: NewsRevolutionary DNA test at birth to help millions avoid cancer and deadly diseasesScientists hope whole genomic sequencing could help predict the likelihood of developing certain diseases from birth and help those at risk to sidestep deathShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsA new DNA test is hoped to save millions of people to avoid diseases "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA revolutionary DNA test at birth could help millions of people avoid deadly diseases. Researchers announced they have carried out , “whole genomic sequencing” on volunteers which can diagnose the lelong risk of cancers. Genetic data from five million Brits will help decide how best to treat tumours and predict how they will react to surgery or chemotherapy. The test, which currently cost around pound per person, also means people at risk of a certain cancer can alter their diet or take pills so they never develop it. Scientists say the gene sequencing could become “routine” and one day replace the current heel prick test at birth. It could lead to genes from every child being sampled in a bid to invent a cancer cure.   The Government says the NHS is the world’s first healthcare system to role out sequencing the human genome on such a scale. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “Sequencing the ,th genome is a major milestone in the route to the healthcare of the future. “Britain has led the world in this amazing technology and we do so again today as we map a course to sequencing a million genomes.Understanding the human code on such a scale is part of our mission to provide truly personalised care to help patients live longer, healthier and happier lives. The DNA sequencing of five million Brits will be taken in the next five years including the comprehensive whole genomic test on one million of the volunteers. Many tumours will not spread but it is dficult to know which are harmless and which will become deadly.Biopsies, chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery can sometimes do more harm than good.  Anonymised DNA data from the patients along with their medical history will allow computers to predict how a tumour will react to ious treatments. Sir John Chisholm, chair of Genomics England which leads the project, said: “The results of this will be felt for many generations to come as the benefits of genomic medicine in the UK unfold. “It should become routine at some point in the future that your health record will contain some form of genomic test,” he added. DNA tests are already carried out on the NHS for a specic genetic mutation or risk. Whole genomic sequencing tests are dferent as they look for mutations linked to  dferent cancers and , other diseases. Since the , Genomes Project was launched in  around , of the , volunteers had rare unexplained diseases diagnosed for the first time.A further , were diagnosed with cancers and given more effective treatment. Professor Mark Caulfield, chief scientist at Genomics England, said genomic sequencing could replace the current heel prick test which tests for devastating neurological conditions. “Currently they do the heel prick test to look for nine dferent conditions,” he told a briefing in central London yesterday. “There may be potential in the future to look at much more and thereby avoid early le harm. “There are some conditions thatyou know about them could change the trajectory of the le of the child. There might be potential in the future to look more at avoiding whole le harm. “We might not feed [the information] to them in childhood but there are some conditions thatyou knew about them at birth could change the le of the child.   “There are examples where we can put children on a special diet or be given a treatment.” Health bosses said in future patients DNA data could be used with wearable biometric devices to flag up the risk of disease before it develops. They also admitted their had been attempts by hackers to access the DNA database. Foreign hackers were behind the unsuccessful attempts to get hold of the genomic data could be lucrative for firms to develop new treatments. Sir John said: “For sure these attempts have come from overseas.” Security measures adopted to protect patient information included employing a company to mount a simulated firewall assault. Since  when the first human genome was sequenced the cost of the process has plummeted from pound billion to just pound.   As the cost falls further whole genome sequencing will become more commonplace and wide-ranging, said the project leaders. A complete genome includes all of a person’s genes plus the DNA that does not directly code for proteins but may influence gene activity. Hidden within the genome may be altered elements of DNA that can trigger or worsen disease, or cause adverse reactions to medicines. Since  when the project was launched automated systems have been sequencing patient genomes at a rate of  a day. The initial target of , genomes has now been met with , sequences officially recorded. The number exceeds that of the , patients who contributed their DNA because every participant with cancer has three genomes sequenced.

title: shock cctv shows christmas party
story: NewsShock CCTV shows Christmas party headlock which left woman with facial paralysisMolly Phillips, , may never be able to smile again after her colleague Nathan Webb gripped her neck at the Cameo Clubs Christmas party in Cardf on New Years DayShareByElaine McCahillJessica Walford:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video work-christmas-party-headlock-left-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking CCTV footage shows the moment a bar manager was placed in a headlock by a colleague at a Christmas party, leaving her with facial paralysis. Molly Phillips, , went to hospital for a suspected stroke but later realised she been strangled by the bars chef at their annual bash. Miss Phillips said she passed out after chef Nathan Webb gripped her neck at the Cameo Clubs festive party, which was held at the bar in Roath, Cardf on New Years Day. Footage from CCTV shown at an employment tribunal hearing captured the moment Mr Webb put his arm around her neck and strangled her, reports Wales Online.  The video, which Judge Alison Frazer refers to in her judgement, shows Mollys arms go rigid as the chef holds her neck and when he releases her, she collapses to the floor hitting her head. The employment tribunal ruled Ms Phillips was unfairly dismissed when bosses failed to properly investigate her complaint that she was strangled at the party. Molly told the tribunal she had since learned that her facial paralysis is more permanent than first thought and she may never be able to smile again. She said she was told her injuries were “were either caused by lack of oxygen or nerve damage”. The tribunal heard that Mr Webb was arrested over the incident but was released under investigation and remained employed by the Cameo Club after the incident.   Molly initially ed to work after the incident and told bosses she did not want to take any action. But as time went on, she became increasingly distrustful and fearful of the chef. Medics also told her that the injuries she suffered would have longer lasting effects than previously thought. Yet when she raised these concerns with the directors of the company, she was told to get over it and ultimately felt she had no choice but to quit.  In her judgement following the tribunal, judge Alison Frazer was heavily critical of the Cameos directors for failing to take her concerns seriously. She said: The fact was the CCTV evidence showed that Mr Webb had her in a hold which caused her to fall to the floor. It was only open to the Respondent to take a view as to what action was appropriate after it had impartially gathered the facts via an investigation. I find that from April onwards Mr Davies acted in a way which was dismissive of the Claimant’s feelings about the incident. He told her to ‘get over it’ when referring to the Christmas party incident. Since the incident, Molly says that as well as her partial facial paralysis, she suffers from PTSD, anxiety and depression. I can’t smile in photographs, she said.  People don’t notice it, but I notice it more than anything. If it’s still like that when I get married, I won’t be able to smile in my wedding photos. Things like that. It’s not nice. But for Molly, the worst bit was the fact her bosses didnt do anything. I’d worked there for two and half years and done everything to that place and it was just like, I realised I meant nothing to them and I was completely disposable, she said. In her evidence at the employment tribunal at Cardf Magistrates Court, Molly said she felt asthe directors didnt take her seriously. When she told director Jason Pearce, she claimed he responded by joking with Mr Webb as he walked past, telling him something along the lines of: “All right buddy  Hear you’ve been choking girls lately’. “I was never askedI was comfortable, how my medical condition was, nothing,” she said. Molly told the hearing that she found working at the establishment increasingly dficult as time went on.   She told the hearing that other alleged behaviour by Mr Webb included putting chilli in a staff member’s soup and threatening someone on a night out. After these incidents, she told her employers she had begun lose faith in their ability “to keep her safe in her workplace”. By March  she said she was “finding it hard to come into work and was crying both before and during my shts”. She told the tribunal: “Around the end of March I was in tears to Huw telling him that I just didn’t feel comfortable in work anymore but I was given the same response over and over, that he couldn’t ‘wave a magic wand and fix everything’. “Meeting after meeting I was just getting that same response and nothing more.” She also claimed she was told in one meeting on April  by Mr Davies to just “get over it, and the same comment was made again on April . In her written judgement, Judge Frazer criticised the directors for not fully investigating at this stage.   Judge Frazer wrote: She was able to carry on at work without suffering any real psychological effects, working alongside Mr Webb, until March. In March the Claimant observed two incidents that made her perceive the Christmas party incident in a dferent way. Rightly or wrongly, she formed the view from these incidents that he had the capacity to be violent towards women. This made her believe that she had been the victim of insidious violence at the hands of Mr Webb. Around this time, she also learnt that her facial paralysis was more permanent than initially anticipated. I find that this culminated in her feeling vulnerable around Mr Webb in the workplace. In my finding there was an inextricable link between the incident at the Christmas party and the workplace, even though it had happened off duty. It was a works Christmas party held on site. She also criticised the directors for their response to the CCTV footage.   She said: Mr Pearce understood from observation of the CCTV that the Claimant had been strangled. Mr Davies, on the other hand, denied that this was the case. Mr Pearce did not watch the video until April or May and Mr Davies only watched it once. And she concluded that because of their actions - and the actions of another person brought in to hear a grievance that Molly raised - Molly was justied in resigning. Judge Frazer concluded: [Molly] was constructively unfairly dismissed. Molly said she had a sense of relief when she found out she had won. It just feels like a weight lted, she added. I don’t want to think about it anymore. Cameo Club said it had no comment at all. Speaking after the hearing, a spokeswoman for South Wales Police said: A -year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of assault and he is currently released under investigation.

title: sir david attenborough makes plea
story: NewsSir David Attenborough makes plea on behalf of Earth as signs of ruin stack upSpecies are continuing to disappear and climate change is generating more problems for the planet, according to ecologistsShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  DEC NewsAnimals and tree species are under threat "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSir David Attenborough has warned the Earth is on the brink of destruction – and the signs can be seen even on our own shores. He issued an urgent plea for greenhouse gas emissions to be cut as he addressed a UN summit this week. Deforestation, pollution, poaching and industrial farming are among the other activities destroying the planet’s ecosystem. Here we look at the impact of human activity on our fragile planet, what is at risk – and what will happenwe fail to cut emissions to stop temperatures rising. Marine Le Fty of the most unusual sharks and rays are on the brink of extinction due to threats such as commercial fishing, including a species whose tail stuns prey.“The biggest myth around sharks is definitely the perception that they are dangerous, that they are man-eating machines – they’re not,” marine biologist Fran Cabada said.Most sharks are at the top of the food chain, which makes them crucial to the health of the oceans. Losing even one of these “living fossils” would also wipe out millions of years of evolutionary history. This is the first time these creatures have been assessed for the Edgeof Existence programme.  Endangered One-in-five mammal species could disappear from UK shores, with the red squirrel, the wildcat and the grey long-eared bat all under threat. Beyond our borders, species around the world are facing extinction – with , on the endangered list. The world’s last remaining male northern white rhino died at the age of  in Kenya this year, a species hunted to the brink of extinction for their horns, which by weight hold the same value as gold on the black market. The last, slim remaining hope for breeding relies on IVF, pairing one of the surviving two females with the semen of a now-deceased male. It joins  other animals of World Wildle Fund’s list including  Amur leopards,  mountain gorillas and  orangutans.Alongside breeding programmes, protecting habitats and global bans on poaching, experts also say,managed ethically, wildle holidays can – and do – provide genuine support to endangered species. This,in turn, provides a financial incentive to local communities help protect wildle.Granada caught spying on opponents and referees with hidden camera networkDeforestation Some , tree species, % of the planet’s total, are under threat of extinction because of degradation or destruction of woodland and forests. In the UK  endangered species are listed as priority in our bioersity action plan. Palm oil is in half of supermarket foods, as well as cosmetics and biodiesel, and the growing demand is devastating tropical rainforests across South East Asia. John Sauven of Greenpeace UK said: “Orangutans have been pushed to the brink of extinction and indigenous peoples’ lives are threatened. It’s no exaggeration to say that keeping these forests intact is vital for all le on earth.” He wants consumers to use products made from existing farms and put pressure on firms to end deforestation. Destruction of Brazil’s Amazon rainforest is at its worst in a decade with , square miles – an area five times the size of London – lost to illegal logging. The ecosystem is home to % of global species but president Jair Bolsonaro wants to limit fines and weaken controls. It would take more than two years to prepare port of Dover for no-deal BrexitImpact on the UK “From Norfolk to North Yorkshire, these communities are already facing the effects of climate chaos and are the ones most at risk of further catastrophe,” explains Friends of the Earth climate campaigner Emi Murphy. “Communities such as Happisburgh, Norfolk, have already seen as many as  homes claimed by coastal erosion in the past decade. “Soaring summer temperatures in the UK led to moors such as Saddleworth burning for days on end… “With a greater risk of summer heatwaves…, we may well see wildfires become a far too regular threat.“York and Leeds, which saw devastating flooding off the back of Storm Desmond in , could also disappear under flood waters,” she warned,sea levelscontinue to rise.“As well as extreme flooding, UK farming is also threatened by the risk of regular summer heatwaves, like those seen this year which left farms across Surrey, Kent and East Anglia parched after weeks on end with no rain.”  Climate Change Global warming has led to a drastic reduction of our ice areas – the snows of Kilimanjaro have melted % since . Arctic sea ice has declined by % in  years and the water flowing into seas warms them, expanding their volume. This has had a major role in raising sea levels up to eight inches over  years, said the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Expert Alesandro Silvano said the rise “weakens currents that trap heat and carbon dioxide, affecting global climate”. Rising heat also has an impact on our deserts, affecting their plants and animals. In some cases this is predicted to increase their size – they already cover a quarter of Earth. Firewood gathering and animal grazing are also converting semiarid regions into deserts.  Coral reefs Marine heat-waves cause by a change in ocean currents in  killed close to a third of the coral living on the Great Barrier Reef - and is unlikely every to recover. But novice ers, of whom there are an one and a half million a year, pose the biggest threat to these erse ecosystems, which support a myriad of creatures, particularly in tourist hotspots, according to James Harvey, operations manager at Reef-World Foundation. “When you look at busy e sites, you often see more broken corals, a lower species ersity and a change in fish behaviour. These corals are less likely to recover from bleaching events. “Novice ers e in an upright manner, with their fins down,” he said. “They kick up sediment and corals use a lot of energy to clean themselves, which makes them vulnerable to climate change and disease.” Other risks posed to marine le by the industry include physical damage from heavy anchors used by e boats, and the oil and other pollution the boats discharge. Thailand, who makes % of its GDP from tourism, this year closed Maya Bay, made famous by Leonardo DiCaprio’s film the Beach, because of environmental damage by tourism. In , it closed  e sites in an attempt to slow a coral bleaching crisis. The organisation advises ers to only use firms signed up to the Green Fins scheme, which helps to reduce their environmental impact.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Storm Deirdre to batter UK with mph gusts tomorrowThe Met Office has issued a danger to le warning as road and rail commuters are told to expect widespread disruptionShareCommentsByNeil MurphyElaine McCahill:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video watch-weather-forecast-next-two-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStorm Deirdre could pose a danger to le as Britain is battered by mph winds this weekend. The weather is set to turn nasty as Met Office forecasters issued a yellow warning for northern parts of the UK. The unsettled system will move eastwards across northern Britain on Friday bringing widespread gales. Inland gusts could reach - mph across North Wales and northern England while winds could hit mph in exposed parts of northern Scotland. Commuters will face signicant disruption as roads and bridges are closed while ferry, rail and air journeys are severely disrupted. Travellers have been warned about the threat of flying debris, damage to buildings and large waves.   The warning is in place from am on Friday morning until midnight. Meanwhile, Thursday is likely to be wet and mild before the unsettled front makes it presence felt from the west. Today will be cloudy, breezy and mild with persistent rain or drizzle in the west. Gale force winds and torrential downpours are likely to cause localised flooding and transport disruption on Friday with between -cms of rain forecast in  hours for parts of the UK.  The Met Office has not yet named the storm as it usually waits until  hours before it hits to to ensure it meets the criteria for severe weather. The National Severe Weather Warnings service says a storm is named when it has the potential to cause an yellow or red warning. A spokesperson for The Weather Channel said: “Based on the current forecast, it is possible that this storm will be named by the UK Met Office and Irish Met Eacuteireann as Storm Deirdre, with high winds and surface flooding possible.”  Storm Deirdre will follow Ali, Bronagh and Callum, which were named by the Irish Met Office and hit the UK across September and October. A Met Office spokesperson said: “Inland gusts of -mph are possible across north Wales, northern England, northern Ireland and all of Scotland, with gusts of mph in exposed locations in northern Scotland. “There remains some uncertainty in the track of this system and where the strongest winds will occur. Heavy rainfall may be an additional hazard across parts of northern and western Scotland.”   Friday: Heavy rain clearing southeast to leave sunshine and blustery showers, but rain continuing in northwest Scotland. Very windy with gales in many areas and stormy in northwest Scotland. Outlook for Saturday to Monday: Showers or longer spells of rain on Saturday and windy in the south. These clearing south through Sunday to leave mainly dry conditions with easing winds but turning colder.

title: universal credit claimants wont christmas
story: NewsUniversal Credit claimants wont get Christmas bonus under new benefits systemUniversal Credit claimants were not told by the Department of Work and Pensions that they would no longer receive the £ Christmas bonusShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsUniversal Credit claimants will not get the one-off Christmas bonus under the new benefits system "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUniversal Credit claimants will not get the one-off Christmas bonus under the new benefits system. Those who are still on the traditional benefits system will receive the one-off tax-free payment of pound but it wont be paid to those on Universal Credit. The one-off payment was introduced to help those receiving benefits with the extra costs of the festive season and is usually paid to certain people in the first week of December. Those who receive  dferent types of benefits, includingPersonal Independence Payments, Disability Living Allowance, or those on a state pension, get the pound payment.Have you been affected by Universal Credit  Email webnews@mirror   One woman, who used to receive Employment and Support Allowance [ESA] before being moved onto Universal Credit, said she was not told by the Department of Work and Pensions [DWP] that she wouldnt receive the bonus. Meryl told the i: “What really angers me is it’s a cut that hasn’t even been publicly acknowledged. Somebody’s just decided that they’re not going to pay this any more, and we’ve been given no more information. “Eventually everyone will be on Universal Credit, so it’s a sneaky way to save money. They’re taking it away from everybody. “Sure, it’s not a lot of money in this current climate, but it’s still pound I would have spent on a gt for somebody  in my family. Our benefits are already being eroded, we’re already getting less money.   “They’re making a cut without telling anybody. It’s another example of cruelty. It’s just death by cuts. The DWP confirmed the cut and a spokesperson said: “Universal Credit claimants have never received a one-off December payment, but many disabled people on Universal Credit will be better off on average by pound month than when they received ESA.” People receiving Universal Credit can still receive Personal Independence Payment [PIP] and contribution based ESA, and would therefore still be eligible for the benefit.   The latest cut comes after it was revealed foodbanks are preparing for December to be their busiest month ever. The Trussell Trust said its network of over  foodbanks provided almost , three-day emergency food supplies in December last year, a % increase for the monthly average for the   financial year. The figure was % up on December , said the Trust, adding that use of foodbanks has been increasing this year. The inability of benefits to cover essential living costs, and issues with payments, remain the most common reasons for people being referred to a foodbank, said the Trust. The five week wait for a first Universal Credit payment had made matters worse, said the charity. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition.  The Trusts chief executive Emma Revie said: Christmas is supposed to be a time for joy but what were seeing is the festive period becoming increasingly stressful for more and more people across the country. Our benefits system is supposed to protect us all from being swept into poverty, but what were seeing is people struggling to heat homes and put food on the table because they simply cannot afford the basics any more and that just isnt right. In the short-term were urging the public to donate generously during the first part of December and into the new year, as unfortunately the need for foodbanks is not going to end after Christmas.

title: smiling law grads celebrate passing
story: NewsSmiling law grads celebrate passing exam - but theres something wrong with photoThe image, posted on Instagram by a New Zealand law firm, appears to show some of the graduates hands clasping at thin airShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsThe picture shows some of the graduates hands apparently clasping at thin air "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSmiling at the camera, a group of law graduates pose with their arms around each other as they celebrate being admitted to the bar.But theres something wrong with this picture. The image, posted on Instagram by a New Zealand law firm, was taken after the young grads passed the challenging bar examination. Andyou look closely at it, you can see something isnt quite right - with some of the groups hands apparently clasping at thin air. This is because the grads - all above the legal drinking age - had been holding champagne glasses when the picture was taken. However, the glasses were edited out of the image by the firm, Simpson Grierson, before it was uploaded to the social media site. The edit was made in a bid to ensure the groups achievements were the centre of attention, according to the New Zealand Herald.The firm reportedly wanted to make the post all about the graduates admission to the bar and how important it is for them. The post, which has since been removed and replaced with a dferent image, read: Congratulations to our  law graduates. This talented bunch was recently admitted to the bar — keep up the good work team. After the digital edit was spotted, human resources consultant Poncho Rivera-Pavon, who is in charge of law graduates and summer clerks for Simpson Grierson, explained why it had been made.He told Newsroom: Were very aware of the media sometimes misconstruing things and making it look like its all about the young lawyers having a drink at work.  We wanted to make it all about their admission to the bar and how important it is for them, so we decided to remove the glasses. A Simpson Grierson spokesman said the glasses were taken out so the focus would be on the graduates awesome milestone. Speaking to Stuff, the spokesman added that the firm was sorry for any unwanted attention that the graduates had since received.The new picture, which replaced the digitally altered snap, shows the group smiling widely while gathered around a sofa.Founded in , Simpson Grierson has hundreds of employees based at offices in Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch.It is ranked among the top legal firms in New Zealand.

title: terrified passenger yells drive machete
story: NewsTerried passenger yells "DRIVE!" as machete-wielding bandits attack carThe American couple were driving on the Old Kijabe Hospital Road in Kenya when they turned a corner and found a white van with three armed men behindShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video machete-wielding-bandits-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple were forced to flee for their lives after a group of machete-wielding men chased them on a rural road in Kenya. The American couple were driving on the Old Kijabe Hospital Road when they turned a corner and found a white van with three armed men behind. As they get closer to the van, the men emerge before they start chasing them while waving machetes. Another passenger in the car can be heard shouting DRIVE while the quick-thinking driver begins reversing up the dirt track.  As the men get closer and begin attacking the car, the driver then bolts forward. A few seconds later a woman in the car says: Are they still there . The driver then says yes before another passenger says they are running away. Shouts of damn and wow are then exchanged between those inside the car.
